title: Chantelle Nicholson's fantasy dinner party — a Thai feast on the New Zealand coast
text:
Tonight will unfold on a beach on the Coromandel Peninsula in New Zealand, surrounded by sky and sea, green valleys, misty rainforests and pristine golden sand. Tailoring the perfect guest list is a delicate art. Mine is a blend of humour, knowledge, fun and royalty.

Having grown up in New Zealand, it would be remiss of me not to invite at least one Kiwi. I have asked the actor and film-maker Taika Waititi, who will supply the jokes. For knowledge, we have Anthony Bourdain, the great chef, who will share all his wisdom and experiences. Michelle Obama will bring kindness, intelligence and fun to the table, and I presume she'll get on extremely well with Nigella Lawson, the queen of cookery and my final guest. Later on, I expect Michelle and her majesty to hit the dance floor together.

Bread, butter, crisps and martinis are non-negotiable. They won't exactly go with the main course, but it's my fantasy so we'll play by my rules. We start with bread from Lyle's restaurant in east London, Bungay butter and Tyrrells salt and vinegar crisps, accompanied by a dry Sipsmith martini with a twist. Next, asparagus with brown butter and poached egg — three of my favourite things. Well, four, if you add in a buttery Grgich Hills Chardonnay 2005.

Chef Wichet Khongphoon is the life and soul of every party and a friend of mine, so I need him in the kitchen. His King's Cross restaurant, Supawan, is a small, understated spot on the Caledonian Road that knocks out insanely delicious Thai food. His cooking is balanced and thrilling. It awakens the senses, which is precisely what I want here.

We'll feast on pla tod naam pla: crispy sea bass fillet laced with fish sauce and palm sugar, with a green apple salad. Yum kamin khao, a white turmeric salad with salted prawns, lime and fish sauce. And Yum koah tod, a salad of crispy, crushed rice balls with peanuts, ginger, coriander, Kaffir lime and chillies, hot and sharp. These are life-giving flavours. And since Wichet also owns the florist next door, perhaps he can do the flowers as well.

If my guests are desperate for something sweet, we can have an apple tarte tatin with freshly churned vanilla ice cream. But I would prefer a cheese course because cheese is another one of my favourite things. On the warm Coromandel Peninsula, we'll have Vacherin with sourdough crisps made from leftover bread (making them zero‑waste), paired with a bottle of Vern from Renegade Urban Winery, which is just a juicy bottle of goodness.
